newsitem.title: BURUNDI: Menengitis epidemic in Burundi kills 73.
newsitem.headline: Menengitis epidemic in Burundi kills 73.

text.p: Aid workers, hard pressed by regional sanctions, said on Thursday they were struggling to control a meningitis outbreak that has killed up to 37 people in three weeks in Burundi's northern Kirundo region.
Meantime, Burundi's Brarudi brewery, a chief source of government revenue, said it had suspended distribution and could stop its operations because of a lack of fuel and spare parts.
Revenue from Brarudi pays civil service salaries.
"If we don't get enough fuel we will have to close altogether. It's as simple as that," said Koos Woltjes, spokesman for Heineken m.v., which owns 60 percent of Brarudi.
But Woltjes gave no date for such a closure.

The World Health Organisation delivered 15,000 doses of vaccine to Kirundo on Wednesday as part of a campaign to control the menengitis outbreak and doctors said an early response by the health ministry averted a crisis on a much larger scale.

"There is an epidemic of meningitis in Kirundo. It started on 24 September and since then 37 people have died," Annick Hamel, Burundi director of MSF-France (Doctors Without Borders) told Reuters in an interview.
"At the moment this is a meningitis alert...but there is a danger that if we do nothing it will grow especially with the onset of the dry season," Hamel said.

Regional states imposed a trade and transport embargo on landlocked Burundi on July 31 in response to a coup by the army that ousted president Sylvestre Ntibantunganya, a Hutu, and installed Buyoya of the minority Tutsi tribe, which dominates the military.

At a summit last Saturday regional leaders rejected a suggestion by U.S. Secretary of State Warren Christopher to ease the embargo and gave Burundi one month to enter negotiations with Hutu rebels or face further sanctions.
They also decided to send a ministerial committee to Burundi to review a stated commitment by Buyoya to unconditional talks.
On Wednesday, the African ministers cancelled a peace mission to Burundi because Buyoya refuses to negotiate with Hutu rebels.

The cancellation reflected a growing rift between Buyoya's isolated government and regional heads of state demanding a return to constitutional legality in Burundi where ethnic war has killed 150,000 people in three years.
The blockade has been somewhat relaxed to allow the entry of essential medicines and limited flights, fuel and supplies for humanitarian agencies and diplomats.
But Burundi's mainly Tutsi capital has remained defiant despite sanctions. Food prices have stabilised and a steady supply of black market fuel has brought prices down.
"There is fuel now and prices have come down from 1,000 Bfrs ($3.1) per litre to 300 Bfrs per litre," a tax driver said.
Beer distribution was suspended last month after four Brarudi staff died in two separate ambushes on beer trucks, Woltjes said in a telephone interview from the Netherlands.
Production of Amstel beer has stopped because it was impossible to import new labels for bottling, he added.
He said Brarudi, which employs 1350 workers, would rather stop production than break sanctions to import fuel or parts.
($1=316.48 Burundi francs)
